security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Wrong colors for some images with custom palette
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Some images seem to be extracted with the wrong colors. Apparently the custom palette is not considered in these cases. The final byte string from

```
['/Indexed', '/DeviceRGB', 164, b'\xed\x1c$\xed\x1e&\xed \'\xed (\xed"*\xee#+\xee$,\xee&-\xee\'.\xee(/\xee(0\xee*2\xee,3\xee-4\xee.5\xee/6\xef07\xef29\xef3:\xef4;\xef5<\xef6=\xef7>\xef8?\xef9@\xef:A\xef;B\xf0<C\xf0=D\xf0>E\xf0@F\xf0AH\xf0BI\xf0CJ\xf0EL\xf0FL\xf0HN\xf1IP\xf1JQ\xf1KR\xf1LR\xf1NT\xf1PV\xf1RX\xf1TZ\xf2U[\xf2V\\\xf2X^\xf2Z`\xf2\\b\xf2^d\xf2af\xf3bh\xf3ej\xf3fk\xf3gl\xf3hm\xf3in\xf3jp\xf3lq\xf3ns\xf4ot\xf4pu\xf4rw\xf4sx\xf4uz\xf4v{\xf4w|\xf4x|\xf4y~\xf4z\x7f\xf5{\x80\xf5~\x82\xf5\x80\x84\xf5\x81\x86\xf5\x82\x87\xf5\x84\x88\xf5\x86\x8a\xf6\x88\x8c\xf6\x89\x8e\xf6\x8a\x8e\xf6\x8c\x90\xf6\x8e\x92\xf6\x90\x94\xf6\x92\x95\xf6\x92\x96\xf7\x94\x98\xf7\x97\x9b\xf7\x99\x9c\xf7\x9a\x9d\xf7\x9a\x9e\xf7\x9c\xa0\xf7\x9e\xa1\xf7\x9f\xa2\xf8\xa1\xa4\xf8\xa2\xa5\xf8\xa3\xa7\xf8\xa4\xa7\xf8\xa5\xa8\xf8\xa6\xa9\xf8\xa8\xab\xf8\xa9\xac\xf8\xaa\xad\xf8\xab\xae\xf8\xac\xaf\xf9\xae\xb1\xf9\xb0\xb3\xf9\xb2\xb4\xf9\xb3\xb6\xf9\xb4\xb7\xf9\xb5\xb8\xf9\xb8\xba\xf9\xba\xbc\xfa\xba\xbd\xfa\xbd\xbf\xfa\xbe\xc0\xfa\xc0\xc2\xfa\xc2\xc5\xfa\xc4\xc6\xfb\xc7\xc9\xfb\xc8\xca\xfb\xca\xcb\xfb\xca\xcc\xfb\xcc\xce\xfb\xce\xd0\xfb\xd0\xd1\xfb\xd1\xd2\xfb\xd2\xd3\xfb\xd2\xd4\xfc\xd3\xd5\xfc\xd4\xd6\xfc\xd6\xd7\xfc\xd7\xd8\xfc\xd8\xd9\xfc\xd9\xda\xfc\xdb\xdd\xfc\xdc\xde\xfc\xde\xdf\xfc\xdf\xe0\xfd\xe0\xe1\xfd\xe1\xe2\xfd\xe3\xe4\xfd\xe4\xe5\xfd\xe5\xe6\xfd\xe6\xe7\xfd\xe7\xe8\xfd\xe8\xe9\xfd\xe9\xea\xfd\xea\xea\xfd\xeb\xec\xfe\xec\xed\xfe\xed\xee\xfe\xee\xef\xfe\xef\xf0\xfe\xf1\xf1\xfe\xf3\xf3\xfe\xf3\xf4\xfe\xf4\xf5\xfe\xf5\xf6\xfe\xf6\xf6\xfe\xf8\xf8\xff\xfa\xfa\xff\xfb\xfc\xff\xfc\xfc\xff\xfe\xfe']
```

apparently gets ignored, as `img.putpalette(color_space[-1])` will yield correct colors (red instead of the currenty gray returned by *pypdf*).

Note: This has been originally reported as (2) in https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/issues/2303#issuecomment-1823199023, but due to being a separate issue, I just isolated it.

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Linux-5.14.21-150400.24.97-default-x86_64-with-glibc2.31

$ python -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf._debug_versions)"
pypdf==3.17.1, crypt_provider=('pycryptodome', '3.18.0'), PIL=10.0.0
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader

for index, page in enumerate(PdfReader('out1.pdf').pages):
    print(index, page)
    for key in page.images.keys():
        print(key)
        print(page.images[key].indirect_reference)
        page.images[key].image.convert("RGB").save("image.png")
```

The PDF file is the same as in https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/issues/2303#issue-2002452594, although it requires some additional work due to the EOD issue there.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Return read data instead of throwing "Unexpected EOD in RunLengthDecode/ASCIIHexDecode"?
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
I am currently experiencing some issues about `Unexpected EOD in RunLengthDecode` when extracting images from some PDF files. Is there any reason to use a hard exception there instead of `logger_warning` and returning the read data?

In a specific case, PDFBox Debugger, MuPDF and Evince are able to correctly extract the image; replacing the exception with a return value in `pypdf.filters.RunLengthDecode.decode` seems to produce an image which only seems to contain the wrong colors.

## Environment

```bash
$ python -m platform
Linux-5.14.21-150400.24.97-default-x86_64-with-glibc2.31

$ python -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf._debug_versions)"
pypdf==3.17.1, crypt_provider=('pycryptodome', '3.18.0'), PIL=10.0.0
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader

for index, page in enumerate(PdfReader('out1.pdf').pages):
    print(index, page)
    for key in page.images.keys():
        print(key)
        print(page.images[key].indirect_reference)
```

[out1.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/13416594/out1.pdf)


## Traceback

This is the complete traceback I see:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/stefan/temp/run.py", line 7, in <module>
    print(page.images[key].indirect_reference)
  File "/home/stefan/temp/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pypdf/_page.py", line 2704, in __getitem__
    return self.get_function(index)
  File "/home/stefan/temp/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pypdf/_page.py", line 547, in _get_image
    imgd = _xobj_to_image(cast(DictionaryObject, xobjs[id]))
  File "/home/stefan/temp/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pypdf/filters.py", line 747, in _xobj_to_image
    data = x_object_obj.get_data()  # type: ignore
  File "/home/stefan/pdf/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 969, in get_data
    decoded.set_data(b_(decode_stream_data(self)))
  File "/home/stefan/pdf/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pypdf/filters.py", line 686, in decode_stream_data
    data = RunLengthDecode.decode(data)
  File "/home/stefan/temp/venv/lib/python3.9/site-packages/pypdf/filters.py", line 343, in decode
    raise PdfStreamError("Unexpected EOD in RunLengthDecode")
pypdf.errors.PdfStreamError: Unexpected EOD in RunLengthDecode
```

comments.body:
Doing some more research, it seems like there are two issues in this case:

1. *pypdf* fails to read/decode the actual image, while other programs just seem to stop there.
2. `pypdf.filters._xobj_to_image` does not seem to correctly handle the palette from the color space definition

   ```
   ['/Indexed', '/DeviceRGB', 164, b'\xed\x1c$\xed\x1e&\xed \'\xed (\xed"*\xee#+\xee$,\xee&-\xee\'.\xee(/\xee(0\xee*2\xee,3\xee-4\xee.5\xee/6\xef07\xef29\xef3:\xef4;\xef5<\xef6=\xef7>\xef8?\xef9@\xef:A\xef;B\xf0<C\xf0=D\xf0>E\xf0@F\xf0AH\xf0BI\xf0CJ\xf0EL\xf0FL\xf0HN\xf1IP\xf1JQ\xf1KR\xf1LR\xf1NT\xf1PV\xf1RX\xf1TZ\xf2U[\xf2V\\\xf2X^\xf2Z`\xf2\\b\xf2^d\xf2af\xf3bh\xf3ej\xf3fk\xf3gl\xf3hm\xf3in\xf3jp\xf3lq\xf3ns\xf4ot\xf4pu\xf4rw\xf4sx\xf4uz\xf4v{\xf4w|\xf4x|\xf4y~\xf4z\x7f\xf5{\x80\xf5~\x82\xf5\x80\x84\xf5\x81\x86\xf5\x82\x87\xf5\x84\x88\xf5\x86\x8a\xf6\x88\x8c\xf6\x89\x8e\xf6\x8a\x8e\xf6\x8c\x90\xf6\x8e\x92\xf6\x90\x94\xf6\x92\x95\xf6\x92\x96\xf7\x94\x98\xf7\x97\x9b\xf7\x99\x9c\xf7\x9a\x9d\xf7\x9a\x9e\xf7\x9c\xa0\xf7\x9e\xa1\xf7\x9f\xa2\xf8\xa1\xa4\xf8\xa2\xa5\xf8\xa3\xa7\xf8\xa4\xa7\xf8\xa5\xa8\xf8\xa6\xa9\xf8\xa8\xab\xf8\xa9\xac\xf8\xaa\xad\xf8\xab\xae\xf8\xac\xaf\xf9\xae\xb1\xf9\xb0\xb3\xf9\xb2\xb4\xf9\xb3\xb6\xf9\xb4\xb7\xf9\xb5\xb8\xf9\xb8\xba\xf9\xba\xbc\xfa\xba\xbd\xfa\xbd\xbf\xfa\xbe\xc0\xfa\xc0\xc2\xfa\xc2\xc5\xfa\xc4\xc6\xfb\xc7\xc9\xfb\xc8\xca\xfb\xca\xcb\xfb\xca\xcc\xfb\xcc\xce\xfb\xce\xd0\xfb\xd0\xd1\xfb\xd1\xd2\xfb\xd2\xd3\xfb\xd2\xd4\xfc\xd3\xd5\xfc\xd4\xd6\xfc\xd6\xd7\xfc\xd7\xd8\xfc\xd8\xd9\xfc\xd9\xda\xfc\xdb\xdd\xfc\xdc\xde\xfc\xde\xdf\xfc\xdf\xe0\xfd\xe0\xe1\xfd\xe1\xe2\xfd\xe3\xe4\xfd\xe4\xe5\xfd\xe5\xe6\xfd\xe6\xe7\xfd\xe7\xe8\xfd\xe8\xe9\xfd\xe9\xea\xfd\xea\xea\xfd\xeb\xec\xfe\xec\xed\xfe\xed\xee\xfe\xee\xef\xfe\xef\xf0\xfe\xf1\xf1\xfe\xf3\xf3\xfe\xf3\xf4\xfe\xf4\xf5\xfe\xf5\xf6\xfe\xf6\xf6\xfe\xf8\xf8\xff\xfa\xfa\xff\xfb\xfc\xff\xfc\xfc\xff\xfe\xfe']
    ```
    For this reason, the generated image is not red, but gray when replacing (1) with a warning and return of the read data. Somehow `img.putpalette(color_space[-1])` seems to be missing, although I am not sure where to put this and when to apply it correctly.

I just stumbled upon another similar EOD case for *ASCIIHexDecode* where just returning the existing data would generate the correct image as well. Thus I assume that *pypdf* is rather strict (too strict?) here.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: IndirectObject warnings from PdfReader#pages result in width of 0.0
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
I've got a well worn piece of code that extracts per page dimensions for PDFs. The code in question is:

```python
reader = PdfReader(pdf_path)
mediaboxes = [page.mediabox for page in reader.pages]
```

When I run the attached PDF through this code, I get the message

```
float() argument must be a string or a real number, not 'IndirectObject' : FloatObject (IndirectObject(720, 0, 140029283788224)) invalid; use 0.0 instead
```

printed 47 times, once per page, and the width attribute of each mediabox is 0.0.

The PDF in question loads in PDF viewers. The PDF was last written by Apache PDFBox 3.0.0, so I'd expect it to be compliant to the specification.

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

I'm running in a Docker container using the base image `ubuntu:22.04`, which I run `apt-get update --fix-missing`, `apt-get upgrade -y` and `apt-get dist-upgrade -y` on before installing python using `apt-get install -y python3 python3-pip`.

```bash
$ python3 -m platform
Linux-5.15.90.1-microsoft-standard-WSL2-x86_64-with-glibc2.35

$ python3 --version
Python 3.10.12

$ python3 -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf._debug_versions)"
pypdf==3.17.0, crypt_provider=('local_crypt_fallback', '0.0.0'), PIL=10.0.1
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader

reader = PdfReader('./Zymeworks_Corporate.Presentation_FINAL1101.pdf.pdf')
mediaboxes = [page.mediabox for page in reader.pages]
dimensions = [(mediabox.width, mediabox.height) for mediabox in mediaboxes]
zero_dimensions = [d for d in dimensions if d[0] == 0.0 or d[1] == 0.0]
if zero_dimensions:
    raise Exception(f"Some dimensions have a width or height of zero")
```

[Zymeworks_Corporate Presentation_FINAL1101.pdf.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/13302338/Zymeworks_Corporate.Presentation_FINAL1101.pdf.pdf)

comments.body: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/issues/2286 may be related - it also is an issue with `IndirectObject` when using `PdfReader#pages`.
Could you please add the complete traceback instead of single-line only error messages?

> Could you please add the complete traceback instead of single-line only error messages?

Apologies @stefan6419846 I should have been clearer - there is no traceback, because no exception is thrown. What I've put in that section is written to the console during the call to `reader.pages`. I've updated the issue description to hopefully make this clearer.
Looks like we're hitting a block that catches and logs the exception: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/blob/112bfabd73c2464eb3c969b6cc94138b44acffc5/pypdf/generic/_base.py#L396

I think https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/blob/3fb63f7e3839ce39ac98978c996f3086ba230a20/pypdf/generic/_base.py#L351 should be catching `ValueError` rather than `Exception`. All the except blocks for the other classes in this file catch `ValueError`. The overly broad exception block is masking the exception that should be thrown (hence I don't have a stack trace to share).

If I make the except block change I'm suggesting, the stack trace I see for my example above is

```
>>> reader.pages[0].mediabox
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/sam/dev/pypdf/pypdf/_page.py", line 125, in <lambda>
    lambda self: _get_rectangle(self, name, fallback),
                 ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sam/dev/pypdf/pypdf/_page.py", line 109, in _get_rectangle
    retval = RectangleObject(retval)  # type: ignore
             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sam/dev/pypdf/pypdf/generic/_rectangle.py", line 26, in __init__
    ArrayObject.__init__(self, [self._ensure_is_number(x) for x in arr])  # type: ignore
                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sam/dev/pypdf/pypdf/generic/_rectangle.py", line 26, in <listcomp>
    ArrayObject.__init__(self, [self._ensure_is_number(x) for x in arr])  # type: ignore
                                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sam/dev/pypdf/pypdf/generic/_rectangle.py", line 30, in _ensure_is_number
    value = FloatObject(value)
            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "/home/sam/dev/pypdf/pypdf/generic/_base.py", line 349, in __new__
    value = float(str_(value))
            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
TypeError: float() argument must be a string or a real number, not 'IndirectObject'
```

The root cause is, as expected, one of the dimensions in the media_box being an `IndirectObject`.

```
>>> reader.pages[0]['/MediaBox']
[0, 0, IndirectObject(720, 0, 140037479660176), 612]
>>> reader.pages[0]['/MediaBox'][2]
IndirectObject(720, 0, 140037479660176)
>>> reader.pages[0]['/MediaBox'][2].get_object()
792
```

What is not clear to me is where the unwrapping of the `IndirectObject` should actually be happening.

Is the appropriate place in `RectangleObject#_ensure_is_number` https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/blob/3fb63f7e3839ce39ac98978c996f3086ba230a20/pypdf/generic/_rectangle.py#L28-L31?

Thanks for the further analysis.

> Is the appropriate place in `RectangleObject#_ensure_is_number`?

At least it sounds somehow sensible there. Feel free to open a corresponding PR and propose a fix for this - ideally including a corresponding test.

@stefan6419846 I'm willing to create a PR. Would it be possible to point out some prior art unit tests similar to the test(s) I should write for the changes to `RectangleObject#_ensure_is_number`, as I'm unfamiliar with the testing expectations for the project?

The testing for the change to `FloatObject` seems pretty clear, I should add tests below https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/blob/3fb63f7e3839ce39ac98978c996f3086ba230a20/tests/test_generic.py#L50-L59 showing that passing an `IndirectObject` to the constructors of `FloatObject` and `NumberObject` raises an exception.

The easiest way is to test `RectangleObject._ensure_is_number` in isolation. Just generate the most common cases as input (`float`, `int`, `FloatObject`, `NumberObject`, `IndirectObject`) and check that the desired value is returned. For the `IndirectObject` case, you might need some mocking/patching to emulate the `get_object` call and the different cases - `IndirectObject.get_object` itself might return another container as well, which probably should be covered here as well.

@stefan6419846  As far as the possibility that `IndirectObject.get_object` could return a `IndirectObject`, if that's a possibility I think we should have a static method of `IndirectObject` to do this anywhere it's needed, called something like `IndirectObject.fully_unwrap`.

It looks like we probably will want to test the constructor of `RectangleObject` rather than `RectangleObject._ensure_is_number` directly, following existing prior art, and not testing private methods.

I'm not really comfortable introducing new patterns for testing using `IndirectObject`, I'm not seeing any tests that do quite what I need to do, and I'm too new to this to want to introduce new patterns without guidance.

Also, I'm not comfortable using mocking/patching to emulate the `get_object` call; in my experience this is exactly the kind of mocking/patching that ends up generating bugs because of subtle differences between the mocked behavior and the real behavior of the actual class with it's collaborator classes. I'd much rather have some test methods that can create proper `IndirectObject` objects in context of a PdfObject.

One option I see for testing is I see a variety of tests that download PDFs; we could create a test using my sample PDF here.
I've created https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/pull/2460 so we at least have a starting point for this change to discuss.

Whether mocking/patching is good probably is a matter of taste. I tend not to generate PDF files for every edge case and instead rely on alternatives where possible, but there generally are different opinions on this ;)

My preferred approach these days is real end to end tests where possible, so you can confirm the real world behavior is what you expect, combined with focused unit tests.

I think it'd be good to have a focused unit test of the RectangleObject constructor, but I'd prefer one that used a real `IndirectObject`, as I think this is a scenario where it'd be easy to get the mocking wrong.

I think it'd be great to have a factory setup for tests to use, so we have one place that contains the complexity of how `IndirectObject` relates to it's `pdf`.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: BUG: Infinite recursion when using PdfWriter(clone_from=reader)
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Use a visited memo to check if the current object in the clone operation has already been visited, and if so, do not add it to the list of objects. This avoids infinite recursion in case there are references to identical objects inside a PDF.

Unfortunately, since the example PDF contains financial data from a client I'm not free to provide the failing example that caused this PR. If you have a suggestion on how to remove that data while keeping the references identical, I'd be more than happy to contribute that. I hope the implementation is logical enough so this isn't needed.

The code that fails is as simple as:

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader, PdfWriter
reader = PdfReader('/path/to/sensitive/file.pdf')
writer = PdfWriter('myfilename.pdf', clone_from=reader)
```

comments.body: I didn't apply the mypy lint to [filters.py](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/blob/9047079045742f09df1a2f5ff40d4b316ec35f7a/pypdf/filters.py#L882) but would be more than happy to do so. My only major question would be then do I need to check if the PDFs are identical for the `id(pdf)` inside (so rather than just the generation and idnum, but also the PDF id)?

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: BUG: Avoid exceeding recursion depth when retrieving image mode
security_issues_created_after_policy.body: Previously, retrieving the image mode could lead to an infinite loop when nested color spaces have been used ("RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded in comparison"). This has been fixed by limiting the default depth which is allowed.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: binascii.Error: Odd-length string when parsing pdf
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Trying to extract text from one pdf page. Parsing crashes.

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Darwin-22.6.0-x86_64-i386-64bit

$ python -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf._debug_versions)"
pypdf==3.16.2, crypt_provider=('local_crypt_fallback', '0.0.0'), PIL=none
```

## Code + PDF

> This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

https://github.com/vors/pypdf-text-parsing-repro (has pdf)

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader

reader = PdfReader("input.pdf")
page = reader.pages[0]
page.extract_text()
```

> Share here the PDF file(s) that cause the issue. The smaller they are, the
better. Let us know if we may add them to our tests!

You can use them in your tests.

## Traceback

This is the complete Traceback I see:

```

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: ENH: Remove only raster graphics
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
The documentation contains two examples regarding image extraction:

- [images extraction](https://pypdf.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user/extract-images.html)
- [removing images](https://pypdf.readthedocs.io/en/stable/user/file-size.html?#removing-images)

This works as expected for pages containing embedded raster graphics. For example:

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader, PdfWriter


# PDF: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/blob/main/resources/GeoBase_NHNC1_Data_Model_UML_EN.pdf
reader = PdfReader("GeoBase_NHNC1_Data_Model_UML_EN.pdf")

page = reader.pages[0]
count = 0

for image_file_object in page.images:
	with open(str(count) + image_file_object.name, "wb") as fp:
		fp.write(image_file_object.data)
		count += 1

writer = PdfWriter()
writer.add_page(page)
writer.remove_images()

with open("out.pdf", "wb") as f:
	writer.write(f)
```
As a result we get two images and a new PDF document without these images. When we change the page from 0 to the last one:
```python
page = reader.pages[18]
```
We get only reduced PDF document:

![image](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/assets/19304263/e3fd66fe-b790-4939-9c3e-3867f2e6cc8f)

Some background images have disappeared (they look like vector graphics) and they are not store in separate files.

This might look like a bug but I suppose that you are aware of that (that's the reason to request a new feature instead of a bug). Nevertheless, it could be great to have a feature allowing to extract only raster graphics to separate files and don't touch vector graphics (or extract them but also with text which might be very hard as I guess).

comments.body:
`remove_images()` is designed to remove all images(and drawings)
This is a new feature. Feasability under analysis

@MartinThoma 
I would like your opinion:
a) looking deeper in the code I've observed that inline images are not deleted with `remove_images()` does not remove inline images. This does not sound normal to me
b) I would propose the following prototype:
```
XOBJECT_IMAGES = 1
INLINE_IMAGES = 2
DRAWING_IMAGES  = 4
ALL_IMAGES = 7
def remove_images(self, image_type:int = ALL_IMAGES;ignore_byte_string_object: Optional[bool] = None) -> None:
```
your opinion

> a) looking deeper in the code I've observed that inline images are not deleted with remove_images() does not remove inline images. This does not sound normal to me

Yes, that is a bug. It should delete inline images (I vaguely remember that this was also documented somewhere)

> b) I would propose the following prototype:
> 
> ```
> XOBJECT_IMAGES = 1
> INLINE_IMAGES = 2
> DRAWING_IMAGES  = 4
> ALL_IMAGES = 7
> def remove_images(self, image_type:int = ALL_IMAGES;ignore_byte_string_object: Optional[bool] = None) -> None:
> ```

your opinion?

Making it more flexible is a similar issue as with https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/pull/1831 .

The solution proposed there is to add a function which gets metadata about the annotation and returns True (delete) or False (don't delete).

That is for sure the more flexible design and allows easier extension.

I'm currently writing a proposal going in that direction :-) Give me a few minutes xD You're too fast xD

I'm looking for similar functions:

* Python built-in `filter`
* https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.drop.html : No callable, just single parameters
* https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.delete.html : No callable, just indices that should be deleted: That is actually pretty nice. Then we have a very clean `remove_images(..., delete_indices=None)` where `None` means all. And if anybody wants something more complex, they need to iterate over the images first and give us the ones that should be removed.
* https://spark.apache.org/docs/latest/api/python/reference/pyspark.sql/api/pyspark.sql.DataFrame.filter.html : The parameter is called "condition", but that sounds not super clear to me in our context.

Weird little finding: I thought `None` might be a bad default as it doesn't sound like "all". The ellipsis `...` might be clearer, but I have only seen it as a placeholder so far. Turns out, one can use it:

```
def mul(a, b=...):
    if b == ...:
        return "all indices"
    return a*b

print(mul(2))
```

I'm not sure if that is a good idea though :sweat_smile:

> ```python
> class ImageType(Enum):
>     XOBJECT_IMAGES = auto()
>     INLINE_IMAGES = auto()
>     DRAWING_IMAGES  = auto()
> 
> @dataclass
> class ImageData:
>     image_type: ImageType
>     ... # potentially more information, e.g. the name, the size, the encoding, position in the page, reference to the image object, ...
> 
> def constant_true(image_data: ImageData) -> bool:
>     return True
> 
> def remove_images(
>     self,
>     ignore_byte_string_object: Optional[bool] = None,
>     to_delete: Callable[[ImageData], bool] = constant_true
> ) -> None: ...
> ```

`ignore_byte_string_object` is deprecating and I'm pretty sure rarely used. I would rather put to_delete in second pos. 
with the type we can identify if to_delete has been forgotten.

also I Propose to have `class ImageType(Flag):`

> Weird little finding: I thought `None` might be a bad default as it doesn't sound like "all". The ellipsis `...` might be clearer, but I have only seen it as a placeholder so far. Turns out, one can use it:
> 
> ```
> def mul(a, b=...):
>     if b == ...:
>         return "all indices"
>     return a*b
> 
> print(mul(2))
> ```
> 
> I'm not sure if that is a good idea though ð

None is more common for me.

> also I Propose to have class ImageType(Flag)

Sounds good :+1: 

> None is more common for me.

Also good :+1: 

> ignore_byte_string_object is deprecating and I'm pretty sure rarely used. I would rather put to_delete in second pos.
**with the type we can identify if to_delete has been forgotten.**

Then it's fine to me :+1: 

What do you think about using the `delete_indices` solution?

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Encrypting - Image color index unchanged
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
When encrypting a PDF with CMYK Indexed color, the colors render incorrectly on the encrypted PDF.
It appears the stream gets encrypted, but the color palette does not, as it is in the dictionary, not the stream of the object.

```
14 0 obj
<<
/Type/XObject
/Subtype/Image
/Width 576
/Height 229
/BitsPerComponent 8
/ColorSpace [/Indexed/DeviceCMYK 18 <0000001200000011000000100000000f0000000e0000000d0000000c0000000b0000000a00000009000000080000000700000006000000050000000400000003000000020000000100000000>]
/Filter/FlateDecode
/Length 2036
>>
stream
....
endstream
endobj
```

The output shows the same CMYK values as the input
```
32 0 obj
<<
/Type /XObject
/Subtype /Image
/Width 576
/Height 229
/BitsPerComponent 8
/ColorSpace [ /Indexed /DeviceCMYK 18 <0000001200000011000000100000000f0000000e0000000d0000000c0000000b0000000a00000009000000080000000700000006000000050000000400000003000000020000000100000000> ]
/Filter /FlateDecode
/Length 2036
>>
stream
...
endstream
endobj
```

In _encryption.py, starting around line 75, we encrypt the stream, but not the dictionary
```
elif isinstance(obj, StreamObject):
    obj2 = StreamObject()
    obj2.update(obj)
    obj2.set_data(self.stmCrypt.encrypt(b_(obj._data)))
    obj = obj2
```

Adding the items of the dictionary, and evaluating them as well
```
elif isinstance(obj, StreamObject):
    obj2 = StreamObject()
    obj2.update(obj)
    obj2.set_data(self.stmCrypt.encrypt(b_(obj._data)))
    # We're encrypting the stream, consider the dictionary too.
    for key, value in obj.items():
        obj2[key] = self.encrypt_object(value)
    obj = obj2
```


Now, the CMYK values are encrypted too.
```
32 0 obj
<<
/Type /XObject
/Subtype /Image
/Width 576
/Height 229
/BitsPerComponent 8
/ColorSpace [ /Indexed /DeviceCMYK 18 <64cda2cefbf39121492b5dfbe74cb864ec4c6101b2675d53c47ae2b5e7591ea3ba6bd2b6bcb1f13eff191f47b9495db796077831f49ac3771b0d0c23eb61418a4df5ddc4945cb16b3b217c86> ]
/Filter /FlateDecode
/Length 2036
>>
stream
....
endstream
endobj
```

Adobe Acrobat will then decrypt the CMYK color values correctly.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: BUG: Infinite recursion bug with PSUtils
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
This bug reports originates with pspdfutils: See rrthomas/psutils#57.

The command `psnup -2 testbook.pdf output.pdf` gives an infinite recursion backtrace.

## Environment

Ubuntu 22.04.

```bash
$ python -m platform
Linux-6.2.0-26-generic-x86_64-with-glibc2.35

$ python -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf.__version__)"
3.15.2
```

## Code + PDF

Minimal example:

```python
from pypdf import PdfWriter, PdfReader

reader = PdfReader("testbook.pdf")
writer = PdfWriter("foo.pdf")

width, height = 595, 841

outpage = writer.add_blank_page(width, height)
outpage.merge_page(reader.pages[6])
```

Note in particular: if I replace the last two lines with

```
outpage = writer.add_page(reader.pages[6])
```

then it works.

Here is the test file:

[testbook.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/12389243/testbook.pdf)

## Traceback

This is the complete Traceback I see:

```
$ python test.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/rrt/Software/psutils/test.py", line 9, in <module>
    outpage.merge_page(reader.pages[6])
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/_page.py", line 1044, in merge_page
    self._merge_page(page2, over=over, expand=expand)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/_page.py", line 1071, in _merge_page
    return self._merge_page_writer(
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/_page.py", line 1224, in _merge_page_writer
    aa = a.clone(
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 297, in _clone
    v.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 297, in _clone
    v.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 115, in clone
    arr.append(data.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields))
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_base.py", line 295, in clone
    obj.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
```

then repeats a lot, before ending:

```
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_base.py", line 295, in clone
    obj.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 297, in _clone
    v.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 115, in clone
    arr.append(data.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields))
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 297, in _clone
    v.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 297, in _clone
    v.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 115, in clone
    arr.append(data.clone(pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields))
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_base.py", line 295, in clone

  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 197, in clone
    d__._clone(self, pdf_dest, force_duplicate, ignore_fields)
  File "/home/rrt/.local/lib/python3.10/site-packages/pypdf/generic/_data_structures.py", line 289, in _clone
    if isinstance(v, StreamObject):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/typing.py", line 1503, in __instancecheck__
    issubclass(instance.__class__, cls)):
  File "/usr/lib/python3.10/abc.py", line 123, in __subclasscheck__
    return _abc_subclasscheck(cls, subclass)
RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded in comparison
```

Thanks very much for pypdf!

comments.body:
the issue is due to the link to the page note and vice-versa which is disturbing the merge function. 
the only solution I imagine would be to discard all annotations, article, and so one but this may remove capabilities that may be useful for other users.

Is there any reason you are trying to merge theses pages onto another page ? Can't it be done in the other way ?ð¤

The `psnup` command takes N pages of its input PDF file and puts them on to one page of its output (often called "n-up" printing). I'm not aware of another way of doing this with pypdf, but would be open to suggestions.

Overall, this is quite a surprising result: I would expect pages to be self-contained, so that combining them wouldn't be a problem; but there may be complexities to PDF of which I'm not aware. (psutils in the past only worked with PostScript files.) If there's no reasonable solution, then I guess this situation should be detected so that it's possible to work with arbitrary PDF files without having this sort of stack exhaustion problem?

The PSUtils package has no interest in the contents of pages; it aims only to reorder, rotate, resize and possibly combine them (as here), while leaving the result "the same" as far as possible. Certainly visually, so indeed discarding annotations etc. would probably be fine for its usage, if there's an easy way to do that?
I will leave the night over. maybe some ideas will come...ð¶âð´

The issue being because of the links,
this is a proposal
```
import pypdf
from io import BytesIO
w = pypdf.PdfWriter(clone_from="e:/Downloads/testbook.pdf")
w.remove_links()
b=BytesIO()
w.write(b)
r=pypdf.PdfReader(b)
ww = pypdf.PdfWriter()
p=ww.add_blank_page(595,841)
p.merge_page(r.pages[6])
ww.write("out.pdf")
```
out.pdf is good then, but links are lost. Sorry

I don't want to delete links as links to web page should work.

Thanks, that's a useful workaround. However, surely this is still a bug in pypdf: I understand that it may not be possible to do what I'm doing, but it shouldn't crash? If I can detect the situation, I could conceivably remove links when they wouldn't work, but otherwise keep them.

Also, I'm sorry, I don't really understand what the issue is here; I'd be very grateful if you could explain further, if possible. I see that on the page that causes problems there are two links which point to each other. Does this create a cycle in the underlying data structure that then causes infinite recursion when it is cloned? If so, shouldn't that cycle be detected?

> ```
> import pypdf
> from io import BytesIO
> w = pypdf.PdfWriter(clone_from="e:/Downloads/testbook.pdf")
> w.remove_links()
> b=BytesIO()
> w.write(b)
> r=pypdf.PdfReader(b)
> ww = pypdf.PdfWriter()
> p=ww.add_blank_page(595,841)
> p.merge_page(r.pages[6])
> ww.write("out.pdf")
> ```

I tried this code, and I get an output file with a single blank page. But, the input page 7 (i.e. index 6) is not blank. Also, the output file is 53KB long. (This is with pypdf 3.15.2.) I can't see anything wrong with the codeâ¦

I've rerun the copied test and this is the output:
[out.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/12505500/out.pdf)
It looks ok for me
Thanks. I don't know what happened, as the file you uploaded is identical to the one I produced, and now both look fine in  Evince.
Fantastic work, @MartinThoma! I looked into this bug myself earlier in the week, but didn't manage to make a serious attempt at it.
All the credit goes to @exiledkingcc :-)
I'm re-opening this so that I don't forget to write a security notice
Thanks very much, @exiledkingcc!
I've just noticed that this gives `RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded` and not an infinite loop. For this reason, I don't think it is security relevant :tada:
Based on your comment I close it (to clean up the database)

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Iterating through images stuck without error
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
When iterating through all images of a certain page, the process is stuck and hangs infinitely (manually aborted after >1h) without any exception or error.
**This is most likely because the example PDF is somehow malformed (but correctly viewable), nevertheless, an exception should be thrown.**


## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Windows-10-10.0.22621-SP0  /  macOS-13.4.1-arm64-arm-64bit

$ python -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf.__version__)"
3.15.0
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal example that shows the issue:

```python
reader = PdfReader(file, strict=False)
writer = PdfWriter()

writer.clone_document_from_reader(reader)

img_count = 0

for page in writer.pages:

     for img_obj in page.images:
          img_count += 1
```


[example_134.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/12309492/example_134.pdf)
(The file is just an excerpt of the original PDF, but still shows the behavior described above)

Here is the rich table output from pdfalyzer:
[pdfalyzed_example_134.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/12309607/pdfalyzed_example_134.pdf)

comments.body:
your Pdf is tricky! you have loops in the resources which should not exists.
However @MartinThoma may consider that as a "security" issue and it is anyway a reliability issue.
Yes! I consider anything that can lead to an infinite loop a security issue as it potentially harms the availability of a service.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Consider migrating to Cryptography
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
## Explanation

I help maintain a large Python distribution, which would like to use `pypdf` for reading encrypted PDFs, but would prefer not to include the additional dependency of PyCryptodome as we already include [Cryptography](https://cryptography.io/) for numerous other dependencies. Cryptography includes the same cryptographic primitives used in `pypdf` (AES and RC4), but is typically a smaller and more secure installation as it calls well vetted implementations rather than implementing them directly. It also is a dependency of `requests` via `urllib3`, and is [widely deployed](https://piptrends.com/compare/pycrypto-vs-pycryptodome-vs-cryptography). A quick check of conda-forge packages showed that PyCryptodome / PyCryptodomeEx was used in 25 packages versus 135 for Cryptography, and other packages such the [`pdfminer.six`](https://pdfminersix.readthedocs.io) have [made this migration earlier](https://github.com/pdfminer/pdfminer.six/pull/456).

If this is something that seems worthwhile, I can work on creating a PR for this effort. 

cc @exiledkingcc

comments.body: +1 the `pycryptodome` dependency occasionally trips up `pip`
good suggestion! i will try to add support for Cryptography. whats your opinion? @MartinThoma

sure, personally i prefer not to replace PyCryptodome by cryptography, add just support using cryptography to do encryptioin/decryption when no PyCryptodome installed. i just write a PR #2000 for it.
and, it's flexible to support any other crypto libraries if needed.

Thank you @scdub for pointing this out. It helps me a lot to know that [requests uses cryptography](https://github.com/psf/requests/blob/cdbc2e271529f467b278b2760f12ee0b5d6930d3/requests/help.py#L30). I need to check [the cryptography project](https://pypi.org/project/cryptography/) a little bit more, bit I tend to agree that this is a good idea.

@exiledkingcc Thank you for providing a PR that swift :heart: I guess it will take at least this week. I don't want to rush with security-related changes

> I help maintain a large Python distribution

@scdub Now I'm curious :smile: In case you don't want to elaborate publicly, but are free to speak about it in private: info@martin-thoma.de

> personally i prefer not to replace PyCryptodome by cryptography, add just support using cryptography to do encryptioin/decryption when no PyCryptodome installed

As I don't want to break backwards compatibility, I also prefer that approach :+1: Was that also the (only) reason why you don't want to change it? If that is the case, we **could** plan deprecating PyCryptodome for `pypdf>=4.0.0`

Regarding the support of Python versions: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/discussions/2005 - currently, I tend to keep Python 3.6 support. I feel like it doesn't cost us that much + a lot of people (sadly) still need it.

personally, i would prefer python standard libraries to have cryptographic functions, which not happens yet :disappointed: . 
for now i think we can keep both as well as they are in good maintation.
@scdub I've merged the excellent PR by @exiledkingcc . The  `cryptography` fallback will be part of `pypdf > 3.13.0` which I will release latest on Sunday (30th of July).

We will likely also switch the order of preferences; recommending rather `cryptography` instead of `PyCryptodome` (and using `cryptography` if both are installed - but I'm uncertain when that will happen).

Thank you for mentioning this issue / bringing cryptography as an option to my attention :pray: I value such contributions; if you want I'll add you as a contributor: https://pypdf.readthedocs.io/en/latest/meta/CONTRIBUTORS.html

> > I help maintain a large Python distribution
> 
> @scdub Now I'm curious ð In case you don't want to elaborate publicly, but are free to speak about it in private: [info@martin-thoma.de](mailto:info@martin-thoma.de)

Thanks much for this change! I really appreciate it. The Python distribution I had mentioned [is what we distribute](https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/arcpy/get-started/available-python-libraries.htm) as part of ArcGIS Pro, a Geographic Information System program. We use your great `pypdf` package (and earlier PyPDF2) to allow users to [create PDFs of their maps](https://pro.arcgis.com/en/pro-app/latest/arcpy/mapping/introduction-to-arcpy-mp.htm) from Python.
@pubpub-zz For sure, I can contribute on a personal basis, and left some thoughts on approaches to support on that discussion.
@MartinThoma you will have to find the good organisation ð

@pubpub-zz specifically on the PDF 2.0 specification, have you seen https://www.pdfa.org/sponsored-standards/ ? It still requires accepting a EULA, but does provide free access to ISO 32000-2 and some of its supplements.

> @pubpub-zz specifically on the PDF 2.0 specification, have you seen https://www.pdfa.org/sponsored-standards/ ? It still requires accepting a EULA, but does provide free access to ISO 32000-2 and some of its supplements.

Thanks, already loaded.ð
The PDF 2.0 specifications became available after I've opened #1660

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

$ python -m platform

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Change in behavior from 3.10.0 to 3.11.0
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
The minimal example below works fine with pypdf 3.10.0, but fails beginning with 3.11.0.  The expectation is that the code would work in 3.11.0, or else a deprecation message would be displayed.

## Environment

Python 3.11.4

## Code + PDF
No PDF is generated due to the error.

```python
from io import BytesIO
from pathlib import Path

from pypdf import PdfReader, PdfWriter, Transformation

LETTER_W = 612
LETTER_H = 792


def create_song_sheet(input_file: Path, output_file: Path) -> None:
    pdf_pages = []
    reader = PdfReader(input_file)
    pdf_page_count = len(reader.pages)

    for page in reader.pages:
        new_letter_page_writer = PdfWriter()

        ## scale the PDF to fit a 8.5 x 11 inch US Letter page
        ## but preserve the aspect ratio by setting the height
        ## to 11, scaling the width accordingly, and centering
        ## the result on the page
        new_letter_page = new_letter_page_writer.add_blank_page(
            width=LETTER_W, height=LETTER_H
        )

        ## set the mediabox width and height so that things don't
        ## get chopped off when we center the scaled PDF
        source_width = page.mediabox.width
        source_height = page.mediabox.height
        source_aspect = source_width / source_height
        new_width = LETTER_H * source_aspect
        width_offset = (LETTER_W - new_width) / 2

        new_letter_page.merge_transformed_page(
            page, Transformation((1, 0, 0, 1, width_offset, 0))
        )

        tmp_pdf = BytesIO()
        new_letter_page_writer.write(tmp_pdf)

        new_letter_page_writer.close()
        pdf_pages.append(
            {"file": tmp_pdf, "name": input_file, "pagecount": pdf_page_count}
        )   

    merger = PdfWriter()
    for pdf_page in pdf_pages:
        ## ERROR OCCURS HERE ON PROCESSING THE FIRST PAGE ##
        merger.append(pdf_page["file"])

    merger.write(output_file)
    merger.close()


create_song_sheet(
    Path("/home/moose/Github/py-pdf/pypdf/resources/crazyones.pdf"),
    Path("out-1953.pdf"),
)
```

## Traceback

Here is the traceback from the file above

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: File Size Increase from pypdf==3.8.1 to pypdf==3.9.0 when watermarking
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
I've noticed that the watermarking process in my job suddenly produces way bigger PDFs. In a specific example with [this PDF file](https://wiwin.de/wp-content/uploads/2023/03/Anlagebroschure-Vogtland-IV.pdf) I've noticed:

* Base is 3.5 MB
* Watermarking with `pypdf==3.8.1` produces a 3.7 MB file
* Watermarking with `pypdf==3.9.0` produces a 5.2 MB file

I'm not sure if the issue is with 3.8.1 or with 3.9.0.

## Code

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader, PdfWriter
import pypdf
from io import BytesIO
from fpdf import FPDF  # pip install fpdf2


def create_stamp_pdf() -> BytesIO:
    pdf = FPDF()
    pdf.add_page()
    pdf.set_font("helvetica", "B", 16)
    pdf.cell(40, 10, "Hello World!")
    byte_string = pdf.output()
    return BytesIO(byte_string)


template = PdfReader(create_stamp_pdf())
template_page = template.pages[0]
reader = PdfReader("template.pdf")

writer = PdfWriter()
for page in reader.pages:
    page.merge_page(template_page)
    writer.add_page(page)

for page in writer.pages:
    page.compress_content_streams()

with open(f"out-{pypdf.__version__}.pdf", "wb") as fp:
    writer.write(fp)
```

## Issue summary

* Root Cause: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/pull/1847
* Fix: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/pull/1906
* Affected versions: `pypdf>=3.9.0, pypdf<=3.10.0`

comments.body:
@MartinThoma 
can you please provide the test code ?
@pubpub-zz I've added the minimal example in the top :-)

> How should I write to a BytesIO stream instead? Would it maybe be possible to point users directly to what they should use instead?

Calling `.output()` is fine, it's just the `dest` parameter that is not necesseray, you can simply get rid of it:
https://pyfpdf.github.io/fpdf2/fpdf/fpdf.html#fpdf.fpdf.FPDF.output

I just tried to find other files that show the same issue:

* `sample-files/009-pdflatex-geotopo/GeoTopo.pdf`: 5.3 MB
* After adding the overlay: 10.9 MB

> It seems to be [2d67c15](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/commit/2d67c15d46a0488e619d3cdf24707feb2d92c224) that causes it. So pypdf>=3.9.0.

I confirm your analysis.
the core problem is identified. solution under building.

This might be a useful test:

```python
@pytest.mark.samples()
@pytest.mark.slow()
#@pytest.mark.xfail(reason="Issue 1897")
def test_compression():
    def create_stamp_pdf() -> BytesIO:
        from fpdf import FPDF
        pdf = FPDF()
        pdf.add_page()
        pdf.set_font("helvetica", "B", 16)
        pdf.cell(40, 10, "Hello World!")
        byte_string = pdf.output()
        return BytesIO(byte_string)


    template = PdfReader(create_stamp_pdf())
    template_page = template.pages[0]
    reader = PdfReader(SAMPLE_ROOT / "009-pdflatex-geotopo/GeoTopo.pdf")

    writer = PdfWriter()
    for page in reader.pages:
        page.merge_page(template_page)
        writer.add_page(page)

    for page in writer.pages:
        page.compress_content_streams()

    b = BytesIO()
    writer.write(b)
    b.seek(0)
    output_data = len(b.read())
    assert output_data < 6 * 10**6
```

with `pypdf==3.8.1` the `output_data` is `5784167` bytes (about 5.8 MB).

@pubpub-zz I think I will make a release with this fix today. I've just updated the first post with a "Issue Summary". I think I will do the same for all new issues. This way it is easier for people to see if/how long they were affected.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: BUG: Transparency is converted to black
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
If I reduce the image quality for https://www.viessmann.de/content/dam/public-brands/master/products/heat-pump/vitocal-200-g/DB-5368770_Vitocal_200-G.pdf/_jcr_content/renditions/original.media_file.download_attachment.file/DB-5368770_Vitocal_200-G.pdf the image on page 2 becomes mostly black

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Linux-5.4.0-150-generic-x86_64-with-glibc2.31

$ python -c "import pypdf;print(pypdf.__version__)"
3.10.0
```

## Code + PDF

PDF: https://www.viessmann.de/content/dam/public-brands/master/products/heat-pump/vitocal-200-g/DB-5368770_Vitocal_200-G.pdf/_jcr_content/renditions/original.media_file.download_attachment.file/DB-5368770_Vitocal_200-G.pdf

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader, PdfWriter

reader = PdfReader("example.pdf")
writer = PdfWriter()

for page in reader.pages:
    writer.add_page(page)

for page in writer.pages:
    for img in page.images:
        img.replace(img.image, quality=80)

with open("out.pdf", "wb") as f:
    writer.write(f)
```

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: SEC: Switch to AES for encryption
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Currently, pypdf uses the security handler revision number 3 (R=3) and V=2. That means:

> "Algorithm 1: Encryption of data using the RC4 or AES algorithms"
in 7.6.2, "General Encryption Algorithm," but permitting encryption key lengths
greater than 40 bits.

RC4 is not secure ([source](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RC4)). At the very least we should issue a big warning + document this behavior. By default, we should use secure encryption methods

AES encryption is not implemented so far. Only decryption.

comments.body:
> AES encryption is not implemented so far. Only decryption.

Is this mean pypdf can do AES decryption without external dependencies? If so, I thought even decryption would only be possible with PyCryptodome.

> even decryption would only be possible with PyCryptodome

That is correct

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Prevent infinite loop while scanning whitespace
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Issue number #1693

I failed to construct a pdf that exploits this. First noticed the issue in pyHanko that maintains a heavily modified for of this lib.

comments.body:
@peteris-zealid 
after checking in the original code WHITESPACE corresponds to (b' ', b'\n', b'\r', b'\t', b'\x00')
therefore the infinite loop does not seem to be possible
also the tests results are showing that the proposed mod has some side effect (tests no more working)

are you still convinced it is required ?

You are correct this PR is not needed.

About the whitespace I did not notice the variable is a tuple (in the fork it was merged into a single `bytes` object). So I was too quick to report a bug.

Regarding comment parsing I still see this as a slippery slope, but did not find any way to exploit that part of code.

After digging into the code I noticed these lines in `read_object` that do handle unexpected end of file while parsing a comment. This is very similar to the code in `skip_over_comment` from `_utils.py` perhaps some code reuse is in order.
```
    elif tok == b"%":
        # comment
        while tok not in (b"\r", b"\n"):
            tok = stream.read(1)
            # Prevents an infinite loop by raising an error if the stream is at
            # the EOF
            if len(tok) <= 0:
                raise PdfStreamError("File ended unexpectedly.")
```
Was this maybe https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/security/advisories/GHSA-4vvm-4w3v-6mr8 ?

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Possible infinite loop in functions `skip_over_whitespace` and `skip_over_comment`
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
If the stream reaches its end then tok will be an empty `bytes` and `b"" in b"anything" == True`.
This can cause an infinite loop for a corrupted pdf.

Some lines for reference.
```
while tok in WHITESPACES:
    tok = stream.read(1)
```

Skip over comment has a similar problem.

comments.body: Thanks for the review do you have any file showing the issue and that can be used for testing ? Can you propose a PR ?
Failed to construct a pdf that causes an infinite loop in practice.

no problem exists after analysis
issue to be closed cf #1694

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Can't add outline
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Outlines can no longer be added in version 3 or higher. The generated file has no bookmarks.

## Environment

Windows 11

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from pypdf import PdfReader, PdfWriter

writer = PdfWriter()
reader = PdfReader(open("test.pdf", "rb"))

# copy original pdf
writer.clone_document_from_reader(reader)

# add bookmark
writer.add_outline_item("Page 1", 0)
writer.add_outline_item("Page 2", 1)

# generate pdf
outputFileName = "test_bookmarked.pdf"
with open(outputFileName, "wb") as o:
    writer.write(o)

```

This results in the following PDF:

[test_bookmarked.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/files/10303954/test_bookmarked.pdf)

As you can see, the PDF does not have bookmarks. It should have bookmarks.

comments.body: Thank you for reporting the issue :pray:

As a quick-fix:

If you replace `writer.clone_document_from_reader(reader)`

by

```
for page in reader.pages:
    writer.add_page(page)
```

it works. I'll add a test this week that shows the issue.
@pubpub-zz You might be interested in this test: https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/commit/cfed01f502afd1af7ed331b32ee84ddd531f9e8a
PR in progress

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Annotations free text chinese characters display blank
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
When creating an annotation with Chinese characters, they are not shown.

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Windows-10-10.0.19041-SP0

$ python -c "import PyPDF2;print(PyPDF2.__version__)"
2.10.5
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from PyPDF2 import PdfReader, PdfWriter
from PyPDF2.generic import AnnotationBuilder

# Fill the writer with the pages you want
pdf_path = 'demo.pdf'
reader = PdfReader(pdf_path)
page = reader.pages[0]
writer = PdfWriter()
writer.add_page(page)

# Create the annotation and add it
annotation = AnnotationBuilder.free_text(
    "Hello World\nThis is the æµè¯!",
    rect=(50, 550, 200, 650),
    font="Arial",
    bold=True,
    italic=True,
    font_size="20pt",
    font_color="00ff00",
    border_color="0000ff",
    background_color="cdcdcd",
)
writer.add_annotation(page_number=0, annotation=annotation)

# Write the annotated file to disk
with open("annotated-pdf.pdf", "wb") as fp:
    writer.write(fp)
```

PDF file: 
[demo.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9806984/demo.pdf)

Actual results: the words "æµè¯" are not displayed normally.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13806929/196350475-a168a334-3703-4e23-845d-01b5622c3af4.png)

Questionï¼
Is it a font problem? Is there an interface to set the Chinese font?

comments.body: I have tried setting other fonts that support Chinese, like simsum, simhei, but it still doesn't work.

You may have discovered it already in https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/blob/main/PyPDF2/generic/_annotations.py#L62.
I found this SO post as well: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/69142800/pypdf2-decoding-issue-when-adding-annotations-in-chinese-characters-with-addjs

I'm not sure how to see what fonts are available to pypdf2. Efforts to change the annotation font type were unsuccessful as you said.

I don't know what the issue is and how to resolve it. But as a small reminder: It could be that the issue is not with PyPDF2 or the generated PDF file, but with the viewer not supporting a feature. Which viewer(s) did you try?
Can you try converting the string to a unicode type string? I'm not 100% positive whether or not the annotations are in ASCII, if they are then you will likely not see support for Chinese characters.
Literal strings are unicode by default in Python 3.

I have a similar problem trying to fill forms with PyPDF2.
Latin's char are displayed without any problem, but thai, arabic, and probably others seems to be displayed in white. When I try to fill the form by hand on Acrobat or Foxit, the foreign characters are displayed, but not when I fill the form on Chrome, or any browser, or with PyPDF2 of course.

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: PyPDF2.errors.PdfReadError: Invalid Elementary Object starting with b'b'

2.11.0

```python
pdf = open("mac malware book objective see/CH 2 Persistence.pdf", 'rb')
pdf_reader = PdfReader(pdf)
obj = IndirectObject(500, 0, pdf_reader)
obj.get_object()
```

Ran into this error trying to parse all of these PDFs: 
1. https://taomm.org/vol1/pdfs/Part%20I.pdf
1. https://taomm.org/vol1/pdfs/CH%201%20Infection%20Vectors.pdf
1. https://taomm.org/vol1/pdfs/CH%202%20Persistence.pdf
1. ...and all the other chapters found [here](https://taomm.org/vol1/read.html)

with [the pdfalyzer](https://github.com/michelcrypt4d4mus/pdfalyzer):
```bash
pdfalyze -r "mac malware book objective see/CH 2 Persistence.pdf"
```

## Traceback

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/uzer/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/pdfalyzer-EerWfplO-py3.10/lib/python3.10/site-packages/PyPDF2/generic/_base.py", line 164, in get_object
    obj = self.pdf.get_object(self)
  File "/Users/uzer/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/pdfalyzer-EerWfplO-py3.10/lib/python3.10/site-packages/PyPDF2/_reader.py", line 1222, in get_object
    retval = read_object(self.stream, self)  # type: ignore
  File "/Users/uzer/Library/Caches/pypoetry/virtualenvs/pdfalyzer-EerWfplO-py3.10/lib/python3.10/site-packages/PyPDF2/generic/_data_structures.py", line 862, in read_object
    raise PdfReadError(
PyPDF2.errors.PdfReadError: Invalid Elementary Object starting with b'b' @27
```

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Infinite loop while reading metadata
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
When I try to read the metadata of [Effective Java 3rd Edition by Joshua Bloch.pdf](https://github.com/bookyue/my_books/blob/53e6378b740807dc7d18f871acbf80ee72962d31/programming_language/java/Effective%20Java%203rd%20Edition%20by%20Joshua%20Bloch.pdf) it takes extremely long. It might even be an infinite loop.

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Linux-5.4.0-125-generic-x86_64-with-debian-bullseye-sid

$ python -c "import PyPDF2;print(PyPDF2.__version__)"
2.10.5
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from PyPDF2 import PdfReader

reader = PdfReader("Effective Java 3rd Edition by Joshua Bloch.pdf")
metadata = reader.metadata
```

The PDF: [Effective Java 3rd Edition by Joshua Bloch.pdf](https://github.com/bookyue/my_books/blob/53e6378b740807dc7d18f871acbf80ee72962d31/programming_language/java/Effective%20Java%203rd%20Edition%20by%20Joshua%20Bloch.pdf)

## Affected

* NOT: PyPDF2<=2.10.4 (throws an exception)
* NOT PyPDF2>=2.10.6 (reads data properly)
* IS AFFECTED: PyPDF2==2.10.5
* See https://github.com/py-pdf/pypdf/security/advisories/GHSA-hm9v-vj3r-r55m

comments.body:
Interestingly, extracting the text works just fine:

```python

text = ""
for i, page in enumerate(reader.pages, start=1):
    t0 = time.time()
    text += page.extract_text()
    t1 = time.time()
    print(f"Reading page {i}: {t1-t0:.2f} seconds")
```
It's the line `obj = self.trailer[TK.INFO]` that takes so long

`generic._data_structures.read_object` seems to be the issue:

```python
def read_object(
    stream: StreamType,
    pdf: Any,  # PdfReader
    forced_encoding: Union[None, str, List[str], Dict[int, str]] = None,
) -> Union[PdfObject, int, str, ContentStream]:
    tok = stream.read(1)
    stream.seek(-1, 1)  # reset to start
    idx = ObjectPrefix.find(tok)
    if ....
    elif idx == 7:
        # comment
        while tok not in (b"\r", b"\n"):
            tok = stream.read(1)
            # Prevents an infinite loop by raising an error if the stream is at
            # the EOF
            if len(tok) <= 0:
                raise PdfStreamError("File ended unexpectedly.")
        tok = read_non_whitespace(stream)
        stream.seek(-1, 1)
        return read_object(stream, pdf, forced_encoding)
```
@pubpub-zz In case you have some time, I would say this is a pretty important issue.

Got it!
the file is corrupt within the /Info leading to infinite loop. Cope with such situation
fixed also a warning on cmap encoding

some other possible issues detected and injected

My concern is about test: the test PDF file does not respect the licensing. I would not like to refer it for testing

The fix was in `PyPDF2/generic/_data_structures.py`:

The `elif tok in b"0123456789+-.":` and 
```
    else:
        raise PdfReadError("...")
```

broke the infinite loop

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: update_page_form_field_values prevents barcode (pdf417) from displaying correctly
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
Here's a description of the issue
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/73533672/pypdf2-doesnt-display-barcode-pdf417-after-using-update-page-form-field-value/73535421#73535421

[pdf417](https://pypi.org/project/pdf417/) barcode isn't displayed after using update_page_form_field_values()

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

* Windows 10
* Visual Studio Code
* python 3.10.6

```bash
$ python -m platform
Windows-10-10.0.19043-SP0

$ python -c "import PyPDF2;print(PyPDF2.__version__)"
2.10.3
```

## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
from PyPDF2 import PdfReader, PdfWriter


reader = PdfReader("i-130.pdf", strict=True)
pager = reader.pages[0]
field_dict = {"Pt2Line4b_GivenName[0]": "Mark"}

writer = PdfWriter(strict=True)
writer.add_page(pager)
writer.update_page_form_field_values(pager, fields=field_dict)

with open("newfile.pdf", "wb") as fh:
    writer.write(fh)
```

The PDF: https://www.uscis.gov/sites/default/files/document/forms/i-130.pdf - you can add it to the tests

## The issue

It works, just doesn't work correctly

comments.body:
Currently , when you are using  `update_page_form_field_values()` you are setting the flag NeedAppearances to true which is asking the viewer to regenerate the appearances of the fields when opening the file : this mean that the "field" of the code is regenerated.

I've started a PR to prepare a fix to not set the NeedAppearances flag but generate the fields Appearance

import re
def rtl_check(txt):
	rtl_chars = u'\u0591-\u07FF\uFB1D-\uFDFD\uFE70-\uFEFC'
	ltr_chars = u'A-Za-z\u00C0-\u00D6\u00D8-\u00F6\u00F8-\u02B8\u0300-\u0590\u0800-\u1FFF'+'\u2C00-\uFB1C\uFDFE-\uFE6F\uFEFD-\uFFFF'

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: PyPDF2 forever spinning at 100% CPU
security_issues_created_after_policy.body:
I want to read this PDF file but PyPDF2 starts hanging forever spinning at 100% CPU while reading the PDF.

## Environment

Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem?

```bash
$ python -m platform
Linux-5.4.0-122-generic-x86_64-with-glibc2.29

$ python -c "import PyPDF2;print(PyPDF2.__version__)"
2.10.3
```
## Code + PDF

This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue:

```python
import PyPDF2
with open("The lean times in the Peruvian economy.pdf", "rb") as f:
  pdfreader = PyPDF2.PdfFileReader(f, strict=True)
  npage = 0
  for page in pdfreader.pages:
    npage += 1
    print(f"Reading page {npage} of {pdfreader.numPages}")
    a = page.extractText()
```

PDF used above: [The lean times in the Peruvian economy.pdf](https://github.com/alexanderquispe/1REI05/blob/37bb0ca495584cf495dba6f1fcdcc9128a8581ec/reports/report_1/The%20lean%20times%20in%20the%20Peruvian%20economy.pdf)

## Output of the script
```
Reading page 1 of 19
Reading page 2 of 19
Reading page 3 of 19
Reading page 4 of 19
Reading page 5 of 19
Reading page 6 of 19
Reading page 7 of 19
Reading page 8 of 19
Reading page 9 of 19
Reading page 10 of 19
Reading page 11 of 19
Reading page 12 of 19
Reading page 13 of 19
Reading page 14 of 19
Reading page 15 of 19
Reading page 16 of 19
```
At this point, the script starts spinning at 100% CPU for more than half an hour when I manually terminated it.

## Preliminary code analysis
The code is spinning in this loop:
https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/blob/84460f54aa4721db36452fe510f8063838e358d5/PyPDF2/_cmap.py#L273-L282
with very large value of `b = 438093348969`. After roughly one minute `a` grew by `9430662` suggesting this loop would running for more than **32 days**. For any other page in this PDF, `b` never exceeds `0xFFFD` which would make this loop finish in about 0.4s.

The lack of comments and the inconclusive variable names prevent any further debugging attempts from my side but, hopefully, this gives the maintainers a hint to what they should be looking at.

comments.body:
Thank you for reporting this issue!

@pubpub-zz This might very likely be an issue where you know best what we should do :-) :pray:

More files where this is happening:
- [Cover 6.pdf](https://github.com/nickstevensMU/navySite/blob/44284bbd9af0ddfcf4a9c0d76b82a5ab1f9bd808/images/covers/Cover%206.pdf)
 (only one page but `b` is `438094010186`)

Another case where `parse_bfrange` is eating up a lot of time (`b` is `65535`):
- [Kubernetes-Cookbook-Second-Ed-Hideto-Saito_146.pdf](https://github.com/pspal83/k8s-repo-dcos/blob/4a56a7a7f52f34b2a065fe02ce101694ce191e15/k8s-master/other/Kubernetes-Cookbook-Second-Ed-Hideto-Saito_146.pdf)
- [PythonNotesForProfessionals.pdf](https://github.com/samuelmoiwa/100-days-of-pythone/blob/6c557b5154526723703db3e8a86f988bc260b793/BOOKS/PythonNotesForProfessionals.pdf)
Although it will eventually finish, reading the PDF takes over 10 minutes on my `AMD EPYC 7502P` CPU. This may simply be expected, though, and nothing we should worry about. However, when this function get redesigned for speed, they may serve as a good benchmark for comparison.

Problem found : the cmap contains a range bfrange which is on multiple lines : this case was not handled. 
PR in progress

Tested on https://github.com/alexanderquispe/1REI05/blob/37bb0ca495584cf495dba6f1fcdcc9128a8581ec/reports/report_1/The%20lean%20times%20in%20the%20Peruvian%20economy.pdf and on https://github.com/samuelmoiwa/100-days-of-pythone/blob/6c557b5154526723703db3e8a86f988bc260b793/BOOKS/PythonNotesForProfessionals.pdf

security_issues_created_after_policy.title: Merging of rotated pages leads to unexpected results
security_issues_created_after_policy.body: When I try to get width and height of the page, I encounter a problem: width and height are misplaced in SOME (but not all!) of the PDFs. The page looks like completely normal A4 portrait document, but using `reader.pages[0].mediabox` returns wrong dimensions `[0, 0, 841.68, 595.2]` instead of `[0, 0, 595.2, 841.68]` ## Environment Which environment were you using when you encountered the problem? ```bash $ python -m platform # macOS-12.5.1-arm64-arm-64bit # and also on every system on docker (Ubuntu, CentOS) $ python -c "import PyPDF2;print(PyPDF2.__version__)" # 2.10.3 ``` ## Code + PDF This is a minimal, complete example that shows the issue: ```python from PyPDF2 import PdfReader reader = PdfReader(path) dimensions = reader.pages[0].mediabox width = dimensions.width height = dimensions.height ``` [dim.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9431818/dim.pdf) I removed sensitive data. ## Output

comments.body: Because this is what happens now with this PDF

From my point of view you issue is with the stamp file.
My first thoughts : 
a) try to change your paper orientation at a different position  (at 'printer' level for example)
b) create a small page just to fit the stamp with a non standard file, and then merge it using translations (https://pypdf2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/cropping-and-transforming.html)
c) use your existing file and find the adequate transformation before merging/rotating

@Nikita7x Thank you for reporting this issue :pray:

I took the freedom to adjust your code so that it uses the new syntax. You might want to check the deprecation warnings (`python -Wall yourscript.py`). 

I've also adjusted the title of the issue as I think it describes the issue better. Do you think so as well or did I get something wrong? If the new title is ok, maybe you can adjust the example code (I guess your're using something similar to https://pypdf2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/add-watermark.html )

I fully understand why the current behavior of PyPDF2 is not as expected. At the moment, PyPDF2 is essentially doing the simplest way. I think we could (and likely should) make PyPDF2 behave as you expect, but we need to make sure that we don't break existing code if we adjust it.
By the way: I love your schematic image for the current stamp behavior :heart_eyes: Did you create them yourself? May we use them in the official docs?

@pubpub-zz We could add an `orientation` property to the boxes (mediabox, cropbox, bleedbox, trimbox, artbox). That would simply be the orientation of the page itself. Adding this property would come with almost no computational / memory / maintenance cost, but it might make this error source easier to spot for users. I'm undecided what I think about the idea myself... what do you think about it?

> From my point of view you issue is with the stamp file. I thought so, but it turns out, it's not about the stamp, it's about the first document. What I've tried also is: - Rotating main document (using` .rotate`,` .rotateCounterClockwise`) - Rotating the stamp file (using` .rotate`,` .rotateCounterClockwise`) - Rotating main document and the stamp file The result is always the same.

As far as I understand the origin of these files: they are being put into a scanner, but with wrong rotation. If you had an experience scanning documents, then you probably remember the guides on the scanning plate, that asks to lay paper vertically. So, some people lay paper down horizontally and after the scanning procedure it appears to be landscape. So they rotate it using software. And after that PDF âlooksâ normal: vertical (portrait) orientation, but on deeper lever it is still a landscape one. And when I use PyPDF2, it grabs information not from âupper levelâ of this document, but from âdeeper levelâ, what causes these problems. 
All of this is only my suspicion and deduction.

> Did you create them yourself? May we use them in the official docs?

Yeah, I made it myself in Sketch. Of course, feel free to use it everywhere

@MartinThoma Apparently the business I'm working at really relies on PyPDF2 and stamping ability. Maybe I can help somehow to resolve this issue? What can I do so that stamp will be applied in place in any document "rotation"? @pubpub-zz mentioned that  
> **'/Rotate': 270**
> The page is rotated at display.

So, what can I do with this Rotate parameter? It seems like applying `.rotate()` `(.rotateClockwise)` rotates it, but after .merge everything is as messed up as it was, just rotated.

@Nikita7x Would you mind sharing the "Rotated PDF" (without the text) and the "Stamp" image in a bit higher resolution with me? I will create some examples + add them to the docs.

I also get confused by this and I need to give it a try. But it's important to note that PDF has two mechanisms for rotating stuff: https://pypdf2.readthedocs.io/en/latest/user/cropping-and-transforming.html#page-rotation

> And here comes the Stamp, this is the exact file I use. I just removed private data

I was talking about the sketch images :-) You could share them just as PNG; I can convert them to PDF and show the effects
[archive.zip](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9438652/archive.zip)

Nice! I think I have an issue related to this topic. So far, I understood that when I use `.rotate()` only the page display is rotated. That's the reason it doesn't work when merged. But I haven't figured out how to make it work.
It seems as if there is a bug and thus the solution I proposed doesn't work: https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/issues/1301
Thank you! I wish I could contribute to solve the issue, but my python knowledge is not enough so far. But I really appreciate the effort you and all the contributors are putting in this project.
@MartinThoma how's it going? Do you know maybe how can I fix this issue myself? My work really relies on that functionality. Maybe I need to rotate it differently somehow?

@Nikita7x 
Under Analysis

@Nikita7x I'm out of ideas for this one (and currently I only have the energy for simple changes in PyPDF2; this one needs more than I can give at the moment)

But you're lucky - @pubpub-zz is the top contributor to PyPDF2 :-)

this are the test files I've used:
Stamp files
[MyStampFin.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9540723/MyStampFin.pdf)      : vertical page with no /Rotate
[MyStampFin90a.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9540727/MyStampFin90a.pdf) : vertical displayed, landscape layout with /Rotate =90

Page to be stamped
[0004.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9540725/0004.pdf)     : Layout page
[998719.pdf](https://github.com/py-pdf/PyPDF2/files/9540732/998719.pdf)  : Vertical page

the use of `page.rotate()` is not adequate as the flag is not taken into account in the merging.
we have to apply transformation before merging. Many points have to be considered for that:
* an error has been found in in transformation.ctm (fixed in #1341)
* be carefull about signs /Rotate is clockwise positive where as transformation are trigonometric (counterclockwise positive)
* rotate transformation center is at 0,0 therefore you need to translate before and after
* the (visual) origin 0,0 is normally on lower/left corner but when /Rotate exists the center moves to upper/left (Rotate=90), upper/right(Rotate =180), lower/right (Rotate=270) and be aware that the axis are turning simultaneously
* when applying a rotation, the cropping area is introduced in content. To prevent that the easiest is to set expand to True

with the following code, I get:
```python
import PyPDF2

reader = PyPDF2.PdfReader("e:/Downloads/MyStampFin.pdf")
st = r.pages[0]
writer = PyPDF2.PdfWriter()
org = PyPDF2.PdfReader("e:/Downloads/0004.pdf")
page = org.pages[0]
st.add_transformation(
    PyPDF2.Transformation()
    .translate(-float(st.mediabox.getWidth()) / 2, -float(st.mediabox.getHeight()) / 2)
    .rotate(90)
    .translate(float(st.mediabox.getHeight()) / 2, float(st.mediabox.getWidth()) / 2),
    True,
)
page.merge_page(st)
writer.add_page(page)
with open("e:/Downloads/MyStamp0a.pdf", "wb") as fo:
    writer.write(fo)
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4083478/189490362-89eb6df5-34ca-40dc-9b3c-073c088adf9d.png)

This can also be applied with the stamp with /Rotate=90 (note the rotation with is reversed:
```python
import PyPDF2

reader = PyPDF2.PdfReader("e:/Downloads/MyStampFin90a.pdf")
st = r.pages[0]
writer = PyPDF2.PdfWriter()
org = PyPDF2.PdfReader("e:/Downloads/998719.pdf")
page = org.pages[0]
st.add_transformation(
    PyPDF2.Transformation()
    .translate(-float(st.mediabox.getWidth()) / 2, -float(st.mediabox.getHeight()) / 2)
    .rotate(-90)
    .translate(float(st.mediabox.getHeight()) / 2, float(st.mediabox.getWidth()) / 2),
    True,
)
page.merge_page(st)
writer.add_page(page)
with open("e:/Downloads/MyStamp90a.pdf", "wb") as fo:
    writer.write(fo)
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4083478/189490952-cbb66a26-824c-4731-982c-d436041f1332.png)

So @Nikita7x  you should be able to get a quick solution

@MartinThoma, @MasterOdin 
In order to improve the API I propose 2 new functions:
a) add a page.get_rotate() function : to retrieve the page /Rotate value
b) add a page.transfer_rotate_to_content() function : to transfer the /Rotate flag into content (apply the good translation/rotations, change MediaBox/... and reset the translation field

Your opinion

That is interesting! I was just wondering if there are other "standardizations" that people typically want to do. That function would return `None`, right?

Sounds reasonable to me :+1:

I then propose to use rotation with a getter and a setter . `.rotate` would be possible with .rotation += 90. Just wanting to avoid slightly different wording for getting and setting.
